attributes.title: A systematic review of psychiatric adverse effects associated with the use of Vilazodone
attributes.description: This systematic review assesses the psychiatric adverse effects associated with the use of Vilazodone as a novel anti-depressant

summary.value: Through research from VigiAccess, it was found there there are many serious psychiatric adverse effects caused by a novel anti-depressant Vilazodone that requires more research.  There has not been any systematic review done previously to assess these psychiatric adverse effects that requires more research and further post-marketing surveillance for the drug.

attributes.title: The Value of Positive Emotions: Do Gratitude and Admiration’s Expressions Guide Third Parties’ Perceptions of Group Values and Personal Characteristics?
attributes.description: Emotional reactions can serve to guide perceptions of group and others. Expressions of negative affect are utilised by third-party observers to classify an action as inappropriate and to infer what makes it inappropriate. We aim to extend these findings by focusing on two positive emotional reactions (gratitude and admiration) in response to ambiguous norm-related behaviours. Considering the antecedents of those emotions in a normative context, we expect the two expressions to impose diverging group values, and different outcomes on perceptions of warmth and competence characteristics. In a within-subjects design participants will be exposed to short written vignettes depicting Person A engaging in an ambiguous behaviour and group member B observing and/or reacting with gratitude, admiration or neutral reaction. Following, subjects will rate the values of the group the actors belong to, and Person A’s warmth and competence. We will test our predictions in a mixed-effect model with emotion as our predictor variable and third-party perceptions as our outcome variables.

q1.value: The Value of Positive Emotions: Do Gratitude and Admiration’s Expressions Guide Third Parties’ Perceptions of Group Values and Personal Characteristics?

q3.value: Emotional reactions can serve to guide perceptions of group and others. Expressions of negative affect are utilised by third-party observers to classify an action as inappropriate and to infer what makes it inappropriate. We aim to extend these findings by focusing on two positive emotional reactions (gratitude and admiration) in response to ambiguous norm-related behaviours. Considering the antecedents of those emotions in a normative context, we expect the two expressions to impose diverging group values, and different outcomes on perceptions of warmth and competence characteristics. In a within-subjects design participants will be exposed to short written vignettes depicting Person A engaging in an ambiguous behaviour and group member B observing and/or reacting with gratitude, admiration or neutral reaction. Following, subjects will rate the values of the group the actors belong to, and Person A’s warmth and competence. We will test our predictions in a mixed-effect model with emotion as our predictor variable and third-party perceptions as our outcome variables.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1a: We expect admiring reactions towards a norm-related behaviour to lead to higher perceptions of group achievement values, as compared to group conformity values. 
Hypothesis 1b: On the other hand, we expect grateful reactions to be associated with higher conformity (rather than achievement) group values. 
Hypothesis 1c: Additionally, we expect these effects to be more pronounced when the emotional reaction is specified (as ‘grateful’ or ‘admiring’), rather than unspecified, and as compared to no reaction at all.
Hypothesis 2a:  We expect that grateful reactions towards a norm-conforming action would lead third-parties to attribute more warmth (rather than competence) to the norm-conforming subject.
Hypothesis 2b: We expect that admiring reactions would lead third-parties to attribute more competence (rather than warmth) to norm-conforming subjects.
Hypothesis 2c: Additionally, we expect these effects to be more pronounced when the emotional reaction is specified (as ‘grateful’ or ‘admiring’), rather than unspecified, and as compared to no reaction at all.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The effects of emotional expression on third-party perceptions will be examined in a repeated measures design. We present 4 random vignettes (out of 25), and manipulate the emotional reaction in each vignette. Thus, all participants will be exposed to all emotional reactions (gratitude, admiration, neutral and none; randomly selected). The independent variable of the study is the emotional expression, and the dependent variables are participants’ perceptions of the group value systems, and of the norm-conforming actor’s warmth and competence characteristics.

q9.value: The study will randomise the order of the emotional expression, but all subjects will be exposed to all four reactions (gratitude, admiration, neutral and none). The vignettes will be randomised across participants such that each subject will be exposed to 4 randomly selected written scenarios (out of 25 scenarios) each ending with a specific emotional reaction (out of the 4 reactions).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Prior to participation in the study, subjects will be screened for self-reported mental health issues and only healthy individuals will be allowed to continue. Once subjects have been successfully admitted, they will proceed with the experiment online. In Qualtrics they will read some general information about the purpose of the study and will be asked to give their informed consent. In each of the four experimental trials, participant will be presented with a short vignette scenario describing an individual engaging in an ambiguous behaviour and another group member reacting emotionally (with gratitude, admiration, or neutral emotion) or showing no reaction to the observed behaviour. Having read the vignette, subjects will be asked to provide their responses to a number of measures considering the individuals in the scenarios. We will measure perceptions of warmth and competence of the actor engaging in the (normative) behaviour, and perceptions of the group values. Participants will repeat that for 4 different scenarios. Finally, subjects will also complete some exploratory measures (perceptions of group injunctive and descriptive norms, effort and ability of the actor and behavioural intentions of the re-actor) and will provide us with demographic information (age, gender). Participants will be compensated for their time with course credits.

q13.value: For the purpose of the current study, a total of 255 participants will be required, based on a GPower MANOVA calculation at an alpha of 0.05, expected effect size of g=0.1 and a 0.894 power. The effect size was chosen as to account for the multiple regression analyses that would be executed. All subjects should be at least 16 years old (cf. local university standards) and have no history of psychological disorders. Participants will undergo a screening process and only individuals with no affectivity-related conditions (e.g. psychiatric disorder, anxiety disorder, and/or post-traumatic stress disorder) will be allowed in the study. Controlling for psychological disorders is important as those suffering from such conditions might experience, express and understand positive emotions in qualitatively different ways as compared to healthy controls (Beblo et al., 2012; Hofmann et al., 2012).

q14.value: Based on a GPower MANOVA calculation at an alpha of 0.05, expected effect size of g=0.1 and a 0.894 power.

q15.value: Data collection will be ceased once the required number of participants is reached.

question.value:
Vignettes. Altogether, 25 different scenarios will be utilised for the purposes of the experiment. All scenarios represent two individuals from the same social group interacting with each other. Individual A engages in a (normatively) ambiguous behaviour and individual B observes and remarks either with gratitude, admiration, neutral emotion or no emotion. All participants will be exposed to all four emotional reactions, but the vignette scenarios will randomly vary across participants such that a single subject will only read three vignettes (each with different emotional expression).
Thus, the manipulated variable is emotional reaction; participants and vignettes represent random variation, to be controlled for using random intercepts.

Unless otherwise specified, questionnaires will be answered on a 7-point Likert scale (1 = not at all; 7 = extremely).

Group Values. To measure the perceived group values, we will implement the Short Swartz Value Survey (SSVS) that contains 10 questions in total, measuring the 10 basic values as described by Schwartz (see Appendix F). The SSVS has shown to have good test-retest reliability and validity (overall r=.64 and .61 respectively) and the values measured by the SSVS are arranged on a circle identical to the theoretical structure of Schwartz’s basic values (Lindeman, & Verkasalo, 2005). The referent in the questionnaire has been adapted to the overall group values, rather than the personal values, proposed by Lindeman and Verkasalo, to allow understanding of the group normative expectation as perceived by the participants. 

Person Perceptions. Person perceptions will be measured with a four-item questionnaire for perceptions of warmth and 3-item questionnaire for perceptions of competence (see Appendix G). The questions for warmth are identical to those proposed by Williams and Bartlett (2014) and adapted to the current scenarios for the perceptions of competence.

To analyse our hypotheses, we plan to implement multiple mixed-effect regression analyses. We expect a main effect of emotion on the dependent variables of values (Hypothesis 1), and person perception (Hypothesis 2). We will further perform some exploratory analyses to look at behavioural intentions, norm perceptions and the extent to which behaviours are attributed to ability and effort. All analyses will be conducted in R and analyses scripts will be made available. Since the study is not set up prior this pre-registration, we don’t have a full analysis script ready at this point. Nevertheless, main effects will be explored with the following code (functions from the lme4 package):
model.warmth <- lmer(warmth ~ em_cc + cc_em + em_gr_vs_ad + (1|subjID) + (1|scenario), data=dat)
model.competence <- lmer(competence ~ em_cc + cc_em +  em_gr_vs_ad + (1|subjID) + (1|scenario), data=dat)
model.achievement <- lmer(achievement ~ em_cc + cc_em + em_gr_vs_ad + (1|subjID) + (1|scenario), data=dat)
model.conformity <- lmer(conformity ~ em_cc + cc_em + em_gr_vs_ad + (1|subjID) + (1|scenario), data=dat)
where em_cc is contrast coded for emotion: – 0.5 for controls and 0.5 for emotion; cc_em is contrast coded for control conditions: -0.5 no emotion and +0.5 neutral emotion and 0 for emotion (gratitude and admiration); and em_gr_vs_ad is contrast coded for type of emotion: -0.5 for gratitude and 0.5 for admiration, 0 for control conditions. We allow for subjectID and scenario to randomly vary.

q20.value: For coding of the expression manipulation, see Statistical models above.

q21.value: We will base our inferences on p-values. We expect main effects to be significant if p-value is bellow the standard 0.05 cut-off point.

q23.value: Should participants not complete their answers to the questionnaire, this data will be removed from the final analysis. Only complete data will be utilised to test our hypotheses.

q24.value:
We explore the effects of emotional expressions on other inferences. Firstly, we will monitor whether third parties judge the emotional reactions of gratitude and admiration to signal norm-conforming actions. Further, we will explore whether behaviours are perceived as showing more effort or ability based on the emotional reaction they provoke. Finally, we will also measure whether the expressions are related to diverging behavioural expectations, such that admiration associates with expectations of self-focused future behaviours, while gratitude - with other-focussed behavioural intentions. 
Manipulation Check. For our manipulation check, participants will rate a list of emotions characterising the observer’s reaction in the vignette on a 7-point scale. The list includes admiration, gratitude, contempt, disappointment, surprise and no emotion. We chose 2 positive emotions (admiration and gratitude), which are also the emotions participants will be exposed to, 2 negative emotions (contempt and disappointment), and 2 neutral emotions (surprise – can be both negatively or positively valanced; and no emotion-in the neutral scenario vignettes). We are interested in whether the participant can recall which emotional reaction was displayed in the vignette. This would be the reaction of the person they read about in the vignette. We plan to use this question just to see if people actually pay attention to the emotional labels (gratitude/admiration) provided in the scenarios. 
Norms. To measure injunctive norms, a 4-item questionnaire will be implemented. The questions are based on Heerdink et al. (2019), and adapted to the situational vignettes in the current experiment. Additionally, we will measure descriptive norms with 2 items (also following Heerdink et al., 2019). 
Behavioural intentions and person perceptions. To record perceived behavioural intentions, we will implement a one-item measure separately for self-focused and other-focused behaviours. Perceptions of effort and ability will also be measured following the main DV.

q1.value: External ratings of major life events

q2.value: Sarah Kritzler, Andrew Rakhshani, Sophia Terwiel, Ina Fassbender, Brent Donnellan, Richard E. Lucas, Maike Luhmann

q3.value:
Research on major life events (MLEs) has often ascribed life events certain characteristics (e.g., marriage has a positive valence) without thoroughly examining these claims. This led to two problems: First, any variation in how people perceive MLEs was disregarded because each event was ascribed one typical profile. It is, for example, often assumed that all marriages are the same instead of considering individual variations in people’s perception of this event. Second, this typical profile was often created by one or few expert raters without examining how it relates to the actual perceptions of people experiencing the MLE. 
In this study, we will collect ratings of characteristics of MLEs from external (lay-)raters to examine how these external ratings relate to event characteristics as they are perceived by those who actually experienced the MLE.

We will use the Event Characteristics Questionnaire (ECQ; Luhmann, Fassbender, Alcock, & Haehner, under review) to  systematically assess perceived characteristics of ten MLEs in a sample of young adults: new friendship, vacation, starting a new relationship, breaking up with partner, marriage, birth of one’s own child, new job, graduation, death of a family member, and serious own illness or injury. The ECQ comprises nine characteristics of MLEs: valence, impact, predictability, challenge, emotional significance, change in world views, social status changes, external control, and extraordinariness.

Please note that this preregistration is only meant to preregister the study design for the study collecting these external ratings. The planned analyses will be preregistered separately.

q4.value: This preregistration is only meant to preregister the study design for the study collecting these external ratings. The hypotheses and planned analyses will be preregistered separately.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Cross-sectional design

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to describe 3 out of 10 MLEs. The survey will be programmed to present each MLE a roughly equal number of times across all respondents.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data will be collected in an online survey. Participants will be recruited at a German university and will be rewarded with partial course-credit. After providing informed consent and indicating that they are at least 18 years old and have not participated in another study related to this project, participants complete a questionnaire on their personality traits (BFI-2-XS). Afterwards, they rate three randomly selected MLEs. They freely describe how young adults will typically perceive the MLE, rate perceived characteristics of the MLEs using the ECQ, and indicate whether and how long ago they have experienced the MLEs themselves. In the end, participants answer some demographic questions, create a personalized codeword and are compensated for participating in the survey. 

A graphical representation of the study flow can be found in the attached file.

data.name: SurveyFlow External Ratings of Major Life Events.pdf

extra.selectedFileName: SurveyFlow External Ratings of Major Life Events.pdf

q13.value: Power considerations (see below) have shown that we need at least 77 external ratings per MLE. Because we have selected 10 events (see measured variables section) for this study and each external rater will be asked to rate 3 events, we need at least 257 participants. Therefore, we aim for a sample of 300 participants with valid data (i.e., who have correctly answered the items to detect careless responders).

q14.value:
We followed suggestions by Cumming (2012) to determine the number of external ratings needed to precisely detect differences between MLEs. The margin of error (MOE, i.e., half-width of a confidence interval), a measure of precision, is related to the sample size. Therefore, the MOE can be used to estimate the required sample size for any desired precision. 

The MOE is a function of the sample size, the standard deviation, and the quantile of the standardized normal distribution. The equation for the MOE can be rearranged to determine the sample size for any desired precision (N = (zquant*SD/MOE)2). To do so, the other elements of the equation must be defined: 
- zquant: For a 95% confidence interval, the quantile from the standardized normal distribution is 1.96 
- SD: We used the highest standard deviations from ratings of perceived event characteristics of people experiencing an MLE (data from Study 5 in Luhmann et al., under review) as an approximation of the expected standard deviation of external ratings (i.e., SDmax = 1.45 for external control of relationship problems) 
- MOE: We use the smallest standard deviation of ratings of perceived event characteristics within an event characteristic as an approximation of the smallest differences we want to be able to detect (i.e., SD = 0.32 for social status change). Again, these estimates stemmed from people experiencing the MLE from Study 5 in Luhmann et al. (under review).

This procedure yielded a required number of ex situ ratings of at least 77 per MLE.

question.value: n/a

We selected the following 10 MLEs based on their relevance and representation in the literature on MLEs and on their frequencies in our studies providing self-report data:
- New friendship 
- Vacation 
- New relationship 
- Break up with partner 
- Marriage 
- Birth of one’s own child 
- New job
- Graduation 
- Death of a family member 
- Serious own illness or injury

We will measure the following variables: 
- MLE: which of the 10 MLEs was rated
- Open-ended event description: For each MLE, participants are asked to write about a brief text on how they believe most young adults would perceive the MLE. 
- Event characteristics: We will use an adjusted version of the ECQ to assess external ratings of event characteristics. Participants will be asked to indicate how they think young adults typically perceive certain MLEs (“Please indicate how young adults who experience this event would typically describe it. We are not interested in your personal perception of this event but in how most young adults would probably perceive it. Please indicate to what extent the following statements typically apply to the event _________ for young adults.”). The items were adjusted to fit this instruction. To reduce participant burden, we use a short version with two items per event characteristic.
- Personality: Five Factor Model personality traits will be collected using the German version of the BFI 2-XS which comprises three items per trait. 
- Potential moderators 
     - Prior event experience: this variable indicates whether participants have ever experienced the MLE themselves 
     - Temporal distance to the event: if the MLE has been experienced before, this variable indicates when it was last experienced
- Indicators of careless responding 
     - 2 instructed response items (e.g., "Please choose answer option 4") 
     - 1 item on the usefulness of the data presented at the end of the survey (e.g., "In your honest opinion, should we use your data?")
- Demographic information 
     - Age 
     - Gender 
     - Level of education 
     - Work status
     - Marital status 
     - Relationship status
We will compute scale scores for the ECQ dimensions and personality traits by reverse coding items when applicable and averaging across all items within each dimension.
This preregistration is only meant to preregister the study design. The planned analyses will be preregistered separately.

registration_responses.q1: External ratings of major life events
registration_responses.q2: Sarah Kritzler, Andrew Rakhshani, Sophia Terwiel, Ina Fassbender, Brent Donnellan, Richard E. Lucas, Maike Luhmann
registration_responses.q3:
Research on major life events (MLEs) has often ascribed life events certain characteristics (e.g., marriage has a positive valence) without thoroughly examining these claims. This led to two problems: First, any variation in how people perceive MLEs was disregarded because each event was ascribed one typical profile. It is, for example, often assumed that all marriages are the same instead of considering individual variations in people’s perception of this event. Second, this typical profile was often created by one or few expert raters without examining how it relates to the actual perceptions of people experiencing the MLE. 
In this study, we will collect ratings of characteristics of MLEs from external (lay-)raters to examine how these external ratings relate to event characteristics as they are perceived by those who actually experienced the MLE.

We will use the Event Characteristics Questionnaire (ECQ; Luhmann, Fassbender, Alcock, & Haehner, under review) to  systematically assess perceived characteristics of ten MLEs in a sample of young adults: new friendship, vacation, starting a new relationship, breaking up with partner, marriage, birth of one’s own child, new job, graduation, death of a family member, and serious own illness or injury. The ECQ comprises nine characteristics of MLEs: valence, impact, predictability, challenge, emotional significance, change in world views, social status changes, external control, and extraordinariness.

Please note that this preregistration is only meant to preregister the study design for the study collecting these external ratings. The planned analyses will be preregistered separately.
registration_responses.q4: This preregistration is only meant to preregister the study design for the study collecting these external ratings. The hypotheses and planned analyses will be preregistered separately.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: Participants will be randomly assigned to describe 3 out of 10 MLEs. The survey will be programmed to present each MLE a roughly equal number of times across all respondents.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: Power considerations (see below) have shown that we need at least 77 external ratings per MLE. Because we have selected 10 events (see measured variables section) for this study and each external rater will be asked to rate 3 events, we need at least 257 participants. Therefore, we aim for a sample of 300 participants with valid data (i.e., who have correctly answered the items to detect careless responders).
registration_responses.q14:
We followed suggestions by Cumming (2012) to determine the number of external ratings needed to precisely detect differences between MLEs. The margin of error (MOE, i.e., half-width of a confidence interval), a measure of precision, is related to the sample size. Therefore, the MOE can be used to estimate the required sample size for any desired precision. 

The MOE is a function of the sample size, the standard deviation, and the quantile of the standardized normal distribution. The equation for the MOE can be rearranged to determine the sample size for any desired precision (N = (zquant*SD/MOE)2). To do so, the other elements of the equation must be defined: 
- zquant: For a 95% confidence interval, the quantile from the standardized normal distribution is 1.96 
- SD: We used the highest standard deviations from ratings of perceived event characteristics of people experiencing an MLE (data from Study 5 in Luhmann et al., under review) as an approximation of the expected standard deviation of external ratings (i.e., SDmax = 1.45 for external control of relationship problems) 
- MOE: We use the smallest standard deviation of ratings of perceived event characteristics within an event characteristic as an approximation of the smallest differences we want to be able to detect (i.e., SD = 0.32 for social status change). Again, these estimates stemmed from people experiencing the MLE from Study 5 in Luhmann et al. (under review).

This procedure yielded a required number of ex situ ratings of at least 77 per MLE.

registration_responses.q8.question: Cross-sectional design
registration_responses.q12.question:
Data will be collected in an online survey. Participants will be recruited at a German university and will be rewarded with partial course-credit. After providing informed consent and indicating that they are at least 18 years old and have not participated in another study related to this project, participants complete a questionnaire on their personality traits (BFI-2-XS). Afterwards, they rate three randomly selected MLEs. They freely describe how young adults will typically perceive the MLE, rate perceived characteristics of the MLEs using the ECQ, and indicate whether and how long ago they have experienced the MLEs themselves. In the end, participants answer some demographic questions, create a personalized codeword and are compensated for participating in the survey. 

A graphical representation of the study flow can be found in the attached file.

q12.uploader.file_name: SurveyFlow External Ratings of Major Life Events.pdf

registration_responses.q16.question: n/a
registration_responses.q17.question:
We selected the following 10 MLEs based on their relevance and representation in the literature on MLEs and on their frequencies in our studies providing self-report data:
- New friendship 
- Vacation 
- New relationship 
- Break up with partner 
- Marriage 
- Birth of one’s own child 
- New job
- Graduation 
- Death of a family member 
- Serious own illness or injury

We will measure the following variables: 
- MLE: which of the 10 MLEs was rated
- Open-ended event description: For each MLE, participants are asked to write about a brief text on how they believe most young adults would perceive the MLE. 
- Event characteristics: We will use an adjusted version of the ECQ to assess external ratings of event characteristics. Participants will be asked to indicate how they think young adults typically perceive certain MLEs (“Please indicate how young adults who experience this event would typically describe it. We are not interested in your personal perception of this event but in how most young adults would probably perceive it. Please indicate to what extent the following statements typically apply to the event _________ for young adults.”). The items were adjusted to fit this instruction. To reduce participant burden, we use a short version with two items per event characteristic.
- Personality: Five Factor Model personality traits will be collected using the German version of the BFI 2-XS which comprises three items per trait. 
- Potential moderators 
     - Prior event experience: this variable indicates whether participants have ever experienced the MLE themselves 
     - Temporal distance to the event: if the MLE has been experienced before, this variable indicates when it was last experienced
- Indicators of careless responding 
     - 2 instructed response items (e.g., "Please choose answer option 4") 
     - 1 item on the usefulness of the data presented at the end of the survey (e.g., "In your honest opinion, should we use your data?")
- Demographic information 
     - Age 
     - Gender 
     - Level of education 
     - Work status
     - Marital status 
     - Relationship status
registration_responses.q18.question: We will compute scale scores for the ECQ dimensions and personality traits by reverse coding items when applicable and averaging across all items within each dimension.

attributes.title: Producing visual explanations of physical mechanisms
attributes.description:
Our ability to learn the causal structure of the world is a fundamental aspect of human intelligence. This causal knowledge allows us to predict future events and perform actions to generate desired outcomes [1-2]. However, acquiring such knowledge directly from the world is costly in both time and effort [3-4]. Thus, it is vital to transmit already acquired causal knowledge effectively, in order to facilitate quick decision-making and advance collective understanding [5-6]. 

The present study explores visualizations as a means overcoming these limitations by conveying causal knowledge in a condensed, exportable format over large gaps in space and time. We capitalize on prior work that has examined how the spatial layout of elements in well-designed visualizations mirrors the placement and relations of elements in the physical world, making it easier to grasp the correspondence among elements in each domain [7-10]. Visualizations have also been shown to promote inference of abstract relations by leveraging a small set of relational symbols, such as lines and arrows [11-12]. 

In particular, participants will draw simple machines (gears, levers, and pulleys), which comprise a unique class of objects that can be rich in both visual appearance and causal information. The study thus explores how prompts to generate visual explanations (e.g., of how a machine functions) or visual depictions (e.g., of what a machine looks like) may affect what participants choose to include in their drawings. Specifically, the study probes drawing behavior by examining how factors such as ink usage, number of strokes, and drawing time differ between conditions.

q1.value: Holly Huey, Judith Fan, Caren Walker

q2.value:
We hypothesize that visual explanations will contain less detail than visual depictions. This hypothesis is motivated by the idea that participants are more selective when producing informative visual explanations than when producing faithful visual depictions.  

Specifically:

1. We predict that participants will use less “ink” in their visual explanations vs. visual depictions, measured by the mean pixel intensity of grayscale renderings of sketches produced in each condition.

2. We predict that participants will use fewer strokes in their visual explanations vs. visual depictions, where each stroke is defined as the mark made between the depression of the mouse cursor (“pen down”) and the lifting of the mouse cursor (“pen up”). 

3. We predict that participants will spend less time drawing while producing visual explanations vs. visual depictions, defined as the time elapsed between the initiation of the first stroke and the completion of the final stroke of each sketch.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Participants will complete a causal learning and visualization task on a custom web-based sketching platform. On each trial, participants will first be presented with a video demonstration of how to operate a novel machine consisting of simple mechanical elements (i.e., gears, levers, pulleys) to activate a light bulb. Following each video demonstration, participants will be prompted to produce a sketch of the machine. Each machine will be trial-unique and characterized by a unique spatial configuration of brightly colored mechanical elements, including gears, pulleys, and levers. Half of these mechanical elements can be manipulated to activate the light (causal), whereas the other half of them cannot (non-causal).

On explanation trials, participants will be prompted to produce a sketch to explain to someone else how to activate the light. On depiction trials, participants will be prompted to produce a sketch that depicts the machine’s appearance so that someone else could identify it. We thus will use a within-subjects design.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Drawing Data Collection
We plan to include 50 English-speaking adults. Participants will be recruited from Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk) and will receive $3.00 for their participation in our ~15 minute study (approx. $12/hr). 

Drawing Data Validation
90 participants, who did not participate in the original experiment and are naive to our research hypotheses, will be recruited from MTurk to judge the validity of our drawing data. Each validation participant will be randomly assigned 1 of 6 machines. After watching the video demonstration, this participant will be shown a sequence of 10 drawings of that machine, randomly sampled from the original dataset. For each drawing, their task will be to judge if each drawing is valid, defined as appearing to be a legitimate attempt to represent that machine. Valid drawings do not need to include all elements of the machine shown in the video demonstration nor be accurate in shape, size, or location of elements (e.g., a blob may denote an element of the machine as long as that correspondence is apparent to participants). Participants may also judge a drawing to be invalid, defined as appearing to represent something else (e.g., a different machine, a different object) or represent nothing at all (e.g., scribbles). Prior to viewing the video demonstration and their set of 10 drawings, participants will be shown examples of valid and invalid drawings so that they understand the validation criteria. 

Each drawing will be validated by 3 different participants. Drawings that are considered valid by at least 2 out of 3 of them will be retained for subsequent analysis.  

See exclusion criteria in the "Data exclusion" section below.

q11.value: We plan to include 50 English-speaking adults. An additional 90 English-speaking adults, who did not participate in the original experiment and are naive to our research hypotheses, will be recruited to judge the validity of our drawing data.

q12.value: Because this is an exploratory study we do not yet have reliable estimates of effect size, so this sample size was chosen in order to obtain enough data to get initial estimates of effect size, as well as estimates of individual & item-level variation. This sample size is also in the same ballpark as other related studies of visual production (e.g., Hawkins et al., 2019).

q13.value: Data collection will stop when 50 participants have successfully completed the study.

question.value:
For each machine, causal and non-causal elements will be equated in size, number, and type (gears, levers, and pulleys) to ensure that they are matched in perceptual salience. 

In addition to type, machines will also vary by two levels of complexity and the demonstration order by which causal and non-causal elements  are manipulated, which follow either an “ABBA” or “BAAB” pattern. The stimuli are thus a 2x2x3 design for a total of 12 unique videos. Demonstration order will be randomized, and participants thus will be presented with and tasked to draw 6 machines. These 6 machines will be randomly assigned to either the explanation or depiction condition.

We will analyze the effect of condition on three outcome variables: the amount of “ink” (i.e., mean pixel intensity of sketches), the number of strokes, and the amount of time spent producing each drawing.

Below are how we plan to specify each measured variable corresponding to the statistical model:

1. Amount of “ink” (i.e., mean pixel intensity)
First, we will attempt to fit the “maximal” versions of each model, including both random slopes and intercepts for participants (i.e., `gameID`) and items (i.e., `toy_type`):

lmer(pxIntensity_avg ~ condition + (1 + condition | gameID) +  (1 + condition | toy_type), data = sketch_dat)

If this model fails to converge, we will remove the random slopes and use the following model containing only random intercepts for participants (i.e., `gameID`) and items (i.e., `toy_type`):

lmer(pxIntensity_avg ~ condition + (1 | gameID) +  (1 | toy_type), data = sketch_dat)

2. Number of strokes
Likewise for numStrokes, we will first attempt to fit the maximal model (i.e., random slopes and intercepts for both participant and item). If the maximal model fails to converge, we will specify a simpler model that only contains random intercepts for participants and items.

lmer(numStrokes ~ condition + (1 + condition | gameID) +  (1 + condition | toy_type) , data = sketch_dat)

3. Drawing time of sketch
Likewise for drawingTime: 

lmer(drawingTime ~ condition + (1 + condition | gameID) +  (1 + condition | toy_type), data = sketch_dat)

q20.value:
Sessions will be excluded from analysis based on the below exclusion criteria:

1) Missing data: If a session is missing at least 2 drawings out of 6, all data from that session will be excluded from subsequent analysis. 

2) Technical failure: Participants will complete an exit survey at the end of the experiment. If participants report that any of the videos did not display properly (e.g., videos freeze intermittently or do not load) or if the drawing interface did not function properly on a trial (e.g., cursor could not draw), their data will be excluded from subsequent analysis.

3) Failure to generate complete drawings: If at least 2 drawings out of 6 consist of a single stroke, all data from that session will be excluded from subsequent analysis. This will ensure that the data collected includes participants that fully dedicated themselves to the task at hand. 

4) Invalid drawings: If a session contains at least 2 drawings out of 6 that are considered invalid by at least 2 out of 3 validation participants, all data from that session will be excluded from subsequent analysis. This reflects the heightened possibility that the same technical/motivational issue affecting the validity of one drawing may have also applied to the remainder of trials in that session.

q21.value: If a session is missing at least 2 drawings out of 6, all data from that session will be excluded from subsequent analysis.

q22.value:
We also plan to analyze potential differences in reaction time, i.e., period of time between the beginning of trial and when participants make their first stroke. This is motivated by the possibility that if participants in the depictive condition attempt to accurately capture the shape, size, and location of elements, they may begin drawing immediately after the video demonstration before their memory decays, resulting in relatively low reaction times. However, if participants in the explanatory condition attempt to draw how elements relate to each other, they may plan how they will represent this abstract information before beginning their drawing, resulting in relatively high reaction times. 

4. Reaction time
lmer(rt ~ condition +  (1 + condition | gameID) +  (1 + condition | toy_type), data = firststroke)

attributes.title: Processing and recall of temporal references at the sentence level
attributes.description: A follow-up experiment in which word-order influence on argument/adjunct recall on a sentence level is tested.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Processing and recall of temporal references at the sentence level 02 - word-order, what, when, where

sample.value:
Responses from about 70 undergraduate students of the Faculty of Arts, Charles University will be collected. Only native speakers of Czech will be included in the data analysis (simultaneous bilinguals with Czech as one of the native languages will be also excluded). This number was set in advance as a compromise between sufficient power and resources available to the authors.

Altogether, there will be 24 experimental items and 96 filler sentences (24 of these will be used as experimenal sentences for a different experiment). Each participant will therefore read 120 sentences in random order during the experiment.

analyses.value:
The data will be analyzed using linear and logit mixed-effects models with the following structure:
   1) Reaction times: reaction time (transformed based on the Box-Cox test) as a dependent variable, word-order and response correctness as fixed effects, item and participant as random effects
   2) Response correctness: response as dependent variable, word-order as fixed effect, item and participant as random effects.

outliers.value:
Participants' response correctness on filler sentences will be measured and these who will score below 70% correct will be excluded from the analyses. 
The reaction times will be trimmed very conservatively, only those data points that were clearly discontinuous in the distribution will be removed.

dependent.value:
In the experiment we follow these dependent variables: response correctness and reaction times.
The experiment is designed as a self-paced reading (with sentence presented as a whole) in Ibex Farm presentation software. Reaction times will be measured directly in this software. 

Since we use open-ended comprehension questions, the responses will be coded manually. As a correct answer, we will accept various response variants which explicitly contain the main correct information (e.g. in the temporal reference is "Sunday", we accept answers like "Sunday", "on Sunday", "during Sunday" as correct, but answers like "on the Weekend", "on Monday" as incorrect).

conditions.value:
Participants are asked to read a sentence and then respond on an open-ended comprehension question. The independent variables are (a) word-order (with two values, see below) and (b) question type (with three values - either a "what-question" asking on a sentence object, "when-question" asking on the temporal reference, or "where" on the locative reference. In other words, the experiment has 2x3 within-subject design. Altogether, there are 24 items and each participant thus gets four exemplars of each condition. 

Item example:
(1) Word order 1 + what-question
Sentence: Starší důchodce v neděli v knihovně velmi pečlivě pročetl noviny.
'An older retiree - on Sunday - in the library - very carefully - read the newspaper.'
Q1: Co pročetl důchodce? 'What did the older retiree read?'

(2) Word order 1 + when-question
Sentence: Starší důchodce v neděli v knihovně velmi pečlivě pročetl noviny.
'An older retiree - on Sunday - in the library - very carefully - read the newspaper.'
Q2: Kdy pročetl důchodce noviny? 'When did the older retiree read the newspaper?'

(3) Word order 1 + where-question
Sentence: Starší důchodce v neděli v knihovně velmi pečlivě pročetl noviny.
'An older retiree - on Sunday - in the library - very carefully - read the newspaper.'
Q3: Na jakém místě pročetl důchodce noviny? 'Where did the older retiree read the newspaper?'

(4) Word order 2 + what-question
Starší důchodce pročetl noviny velmi pečlivě v neděli v knihovně.
'An older retiree - read the newspaper - very carefully - on Sunday - in the library.'
Q1: Co pročetl důchodce? 'What did the older retiree read?'

(5) Word order 2 + when-question
Starší důchodce pročetl noviny velmi pečlivě v neděli v knihovně.
'An older retiree - read the newspaper - very carefully - on Sunday - in the library.'
Q2: Kdy pročetl důchodce noviny? 'When did the older retiree read the newspaper?'

(6) Word order 2 + where-question
Starší důchodce pročetl noviny velmi pečlivě v neděli v knihovně.
'An older retiree - read the newspaper - very carefully - on Sunday - in the library.'
Q3: Na jakém místě pročetl důchodce noviny? 'Where did the older retiree read the newspaper?'

hypothesis.value:
The aim of the experiment is to examine information recall at the sentential level. In a prior experiment, we observed that objects were generally recalled better than temporal references. In this experiment, our aim is to (a) replicate these findings, (b) also test locative references. To reach our goal, we compare sentences with a different word-order position of targeted sentence elements. The elements appear either in the most prominent or in a less prominent position in the middle of the sentence.

In sum, our hypotheses are as follows:
(1) Temporal references will be recalled worse than object references.
(2) Locative references will be recalled worse than object references.
(3) The success rate in recalling temporal and locative references will not differ.
(4) The sentence final position of a reference will yield higher recall success rate.

attributes.title: Do Binaural Beats affect Vigilance?
attributes.description: Binaural Beats have two different frequency tones which oscillate to produce different effects. Each of these beats operates in different frequencies thus having different sound production: theta, delta, alpha, beta, and gamma. In the experiment beta Binaural Beats with frequencies of 200 and 216 Hertz, Hz (unit of measurement for frequency), were used with a control of 200 Hz flat noise. The experiment utilized the psychomotor vigilance task to measure changes in response times and utilized Affectiva to measure changes in facial musculature. The response times were then analyzed to explain why the Binaural Beats condition had significantly shorter response times compared to the control group throughout the task. In terms of emotional change, some trends were noticed for the Binaural Beats and the control condition; however, none of the trends were significant. Moving forward with the experiment, an increased number of participants can be recorded to strengthen the validity and test different frequencies of Binaural Beats for accuracy.

q1.value: The Effect of Binaural Beats on Vigilance and Mood

q2.value: Mohitha Obulasetty, Gene Brewer, Kimberly Wingert, Matthew Robison

q3.value: There have been many previous studies that have shown that Binaural Beats affect vigilance, working memory and mood in a positive direction. All the previous studies have measured the vigilance data through using choice tasks (participant has to make a choice to continue the task) and mood data through various paper analysis issued at the beginning and end of task. Therefore, we will measure two different Binaural Beat sounds that effects both the vigilance decrement task and mood through continuous facial monitor.

q4.value:
Binaural Beats will effect vigilance in that they would reduce the response times either through lower amount of distraction times or would allow for consistent response times all through out. 
Binaural Beats will increase vigilance through increasing consistency for faster response times and decreasing distractions to further increase response times. When Binaural Beats are played, the anger in the mood will be delayed.

q5.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q6.value: An appropriate instance of using the existing data would be to get a sample size. With the usage of previous studies that studied binaural beats and vigilance, G-powered analysis and effect size measures will be done to achieve an optimal sample size to provide generalization and effects. After registration, the experiment will be conducted on participants based on the sample sizes that was previously gathered.

question.value: Participants will be recruited from ASU Psychology 101 class. The students will receive 0.5 credits as the study spans 30 minutes. Participants must be 18 years or older to sign the informed consent as we are also measuring and storing their facial expressions. The study is a double blind study to limit any biases. However, the only exclusion for participants would be that they can't have defects in their hearing. The study will go on until we have attained at least 200 participants.

q8.value: I am planning to collect at least 210 people, with 105 people in control and experimental groups. The people will also be randomly assigned and they won't know which group the person belongs to.

q9.value: I used the software program called G Power to conduct a power analysis. From the previous studies, the eta squared should equal 0.11. Also, our goal was to obtain 0.95 power with a 0.05 alpha error probability.

q10.value: We will collect students until we have reached about 210 participants in total. We also post multiple open slots for ASU Psychology students to sign-up at the end of each week.

question.value: We manipulated the presence of Binaural Beats. For the control group, we had a flat noise level at exactly 200 Hz, while the experimental group had the binaural beats playing. The beats were 200 Hz in the right ear and 216 Hz in the left ear playing at the same time to produce oscillations.

We will be measuring several variables: psychomotor vigilance task, and changes in facial expression. For the psychomotor vigilance task, we will be measuring the reaction times of the participants. The participants will have to press the space bar as soon as the timer starts to increase. The faster the participants press the space bar, the lower the reaction times. 

For the changes in the facial expressions, we will be measuring the correlation between the emotions of anger, annoyance, boredom contrasted with the emotions of happiness and joy. The video recording will continue throughout the experiment, so the progression and the exact times when the participants start to change their emotions will be recorded.

We will be doing measurements on both the psychomotor vigilance task and the changes in facial expressions. For the psychomotor vigilance task, we will be doing the vigilance decrement, Coefficient of variability, and the Ex-Gaussian Model. For the vigilance decrement, we will be plotting data points on when the participants start to drastically increase in their reaction times. For the coefficient of variability, we will be measuring the variability between all the trials for with-in group and between group participants. For the Ex-Gaussian model, we will be plotting the response times.

For the change in facial expression task, we will be using the software called Affectiva to track the changes in facial expressions throughout the experiment.

q14.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Research personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments.
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: We have a 2 by 2 study design. The independent variable would be whether the participant is listening to Binaural beats or flat tone. The dependent variable is measuring the response times for the psychomotor vigilance task and the change in facial expressions throughout the experiment. This study is also unpaired, and it is between subjects design. The participants will be randomized before the study begins, so we can avoid any confound variables that might arise.

q17.value: We will be randomizing participants based on the random numbers that the computer generates. Before the experiment begins, each participant will be given a random number in which they will use to access the experiment. Based on the number, the participants will either be placed in the experimental or the control group.

question.value: We will be doing a 2 factor non-repeated measures ANOVA test to analyze our results. The independent variable is whether the Binaural beats were played while the dependent variable is the response times for the psychomotor vigilance task.  We will also be measuring for the changes in mood of facial expressions throughout the study. There are two interactions that will be measured: binaural beats and response times; binaural beats and changes in facial expression.

q20.value: The only variable we will be coding is binaural beats. If the binaural beats were played, then it would be coded as 1, and if binaural beats weren't played, then it would be coded as 0.

q21.value: If the ANOVA indicated that the mean of binaural beats and emotions are significantly different (p<0.05), then we will use a Q-statistics as a post-hoc test to measure where the difference lie.

q22.value: We will use the standard p<0.05 to determine if ANOVA suggests that the results are significantly different for Binaural Beats or not. Then, if there is a significance, we can do a post-hoc test to determine where the difference lies.

q23.value:
The outliers will be counted because we are measuring the rate of change in response time over time. So we will take the person's baseline times in the beginning of the study, and see how these response times will change over 20 minutes throughout the experiment. 

we will delete the trial times and the ending where the experiment actually ends. We will delete the response times that are outliers to the mean of the sample.
